news.title: AA Snap: Democratizing Account Abstraction
news.subtitle: An ETHIndia Hackathon Winner

childMarkdownRemark.html:
MetaMask Snaps is the roadmap to making MetaMask the most extensible wallet in the world. As a developer, you can bring your features and APIs to MetaMask in totally new ways. Web3 developers are the core of this growth and this series aims to showcase the novel MetMask Snaps being built today.

AA Snap

Snap Repo: https://github.com/a42io/AAsnap

Why did you build it?

AA Snap is built for democratizing Account Abstraction (AA) for all developers and users. We believe AA will be widely used in the future. However, currently, it takes work for devs to integrate it with their dapps and for users to use it.

From devs' perspective, it's necessary to write additional code that supports AA in addition to EOA.

From users' point of view, they cannot use their usual wallets, such as MetaMask, and need to install another wallet that supports AA, which is a bad UX.

Therefore, we wanted to make it easy to integrate and use AA by utilizing MetaMask Snaps.

Can you walk us through the technical implementation?

AA Snap is composed of three components: an example frontend, the MetaMask snap, and a temporary server. The snap enables devs and users to use an AA wallet (a contract wallet that supports EIP-4337) very easily. Please see the repository for the full implementation.

The example frontend

The example frontend is based on the template that is provided by MetaMask. It shows developers can easily integrate AA with their dapps by AA Snap.

For example, a balance of the AA wallet can be fetched with the simple code below.

const balance = (await window.ethereum.request({
    method: 'wallet_invokeSnap',
    params: [
        defaultSnapOrigin,
        {
            method: 'balance',
        },
    ],
})) as string;

To send a transaction from the AA wallet, you can just write the code below by passing a beneficiary address and value.

await window.ethereum.request({
    method: 'wallet_invokeSnap',
    params: [
        defaultSnapOrigin,
        {
            method: 'transfer',
            params: {
                to,        // beneficiary address
                value,     // value in ETH or MATIC
            },
        },
    ],
});

How easy is it to use the AA wallet from the user’s perspective? Try it here: https://AAsn.app

The Snap

The snap gets an instance of AA with the code below. To implement AA, we used the @account-abstraction/sdk npm package.

Since the AA wallet address can be deterministically derived from the user’s EOA, no user input is required.

export const getAbstractAccount = async (): Promise<SimpleAccountAPI> => {
    const provider = new ethers.providers.Web3Provider(wallet as any);
    await provider.send('eth_requestAccounts', []);
    const owner = provider.getSigner();
    const aa = new SimpleAccountAPI({
        provider,
        entryPointAddress,
        owner,
        factoryAddress,
    });
    return aa;
};

There are three steps to send a transaction from the AA wallet:

  1. The snap shows a confirmation within the MetaMask using the snap’s snap_confirm method. This process is not required but is needed for better UX because there’s no way for users to know the details of what they will sign.
  2. The code creates a user operation of the AA wallet and requests to sign a hash of the user operation. This process is almost the same as creating a tx from EOA and signing it.
  3. Send the signed user operation to a bundler via our server.
export const transfer = async (target: string, ethValue: string) => {
    const value = ethers.utils.parseEther(ethValue);
    const aa = await getAbstractAccount();
    const address = await aa.getAccountAddress();

    // 1. Show confirmation within MetaMask
    const result = await wallet.request({
        method: 'snap_confirm',
        params: [{
            prompt: 'Transfer',
            description: 'Transfer from your Abstraction Account',
            textAreaContent: `from: ${address}\ntarget: ${target}\nvalue: ${ethValue}`,
        }],
    });

    if (!result) {
        return;
    }

    // 2. Create a signed user operation of AA wallet
    const op = await aa.createSignedUserOp({
        target,
        value,
        data: '0x',
        maxFeePerGas,
        maxPriorityFeePerGas,
    });

    const printedOp = await printOp(op);
    const body = JSON.stringify({
        op: printedOp,
    });

    // 3. Send a signed user operation to the bundler
    const response = await fetch(SERVER_END_POINT {
        method: 'POST',
        headers: {
            'Content-Type': 'application/json',
        },
        body,
    });
};

The temporary server

During the hackathon, we encountered an error when calling the sendUserOpToBundler method inside the snap. Since we didn’t have time to dig into the issue, we decided to create a server to solve the problem temporarily. The temporary server just receives the signed user operation and passes it to a bundler.

Because of the error probably came from dependencies because there are some restrictions in the MetaMask Snaps execution environment. We think the temporary server can be removed by following this document: Patching Dependencies

app.post('/aa', async (req, res) => {
  const provider = new ethers.providers.JsonRpcProvider(
    process.env.RPC_ENDPOINT,
  );
  const client = await getHttpRpcClient(
    provider,
    process.env.BUNDLER_URL as string,
    process.env.ENTRY_POINT_ADDRESS as string,
  );

  try {
    const uoHash = await client.sendUserOpToBundler(JSON.parse(req.body.op));
    return res.json({
      uoHash,
    });
  } catch (e) {
    console.log(e);
    return res.status(400).send();
  }
});

What are the next steps if you would implement this?

We would like to remove unnecessary server-side code and run the snap alone. Also, currently, it is possible for the MetaMask Snaps developer like us to replace a transaction hash to be signed with a malicious one, so we would like to introduce or propose a mechanism to prevent it.

Can you tell us a little bit about yourself and your team?

Our team is running a small startup - a42 - in Japan and Singapore. a42 is building a Web3 smart lock "wΞlock" that enables auth with smart contracts including NFT and ENS: https://a42.io/w3lock In 2022, we attended several hackathons to learn new technologies like MetaMask Snaps.

Hideyoshi Moriya (piyo.eth): Hideyoshi has been experimenting and building Ethereum based apps since 2017. He developed a collaborative NFT art project "Pixereum" in 2017. He worked at Google as a technical product specialist and started his company "a42" in 2019. In a42, he develops dapps that can work in the real world. He is currently developing a Web3 smart lock "wΞlock" that can be opened by ENS/NFT based on the PoC he developed in 2021: https://twitter.com/hm0429/status/1465241679800111107

Hiroyuki Tachibana (tachibana.eth): Hiroyuki is a co-founder and engineer at a42. He led a project to build a blockchain auth module for IoT devices "w3a.io" and received a grant from Ethereum Foundation. He received several prizes at ETHGlobal hackathons through 2022. He is currently developing a zkp privacy solution for the Web3 smart lock product.

Yusuke Moriya (yskmyskm.eth): Yusuke is a designer at a42. He worked as CG / VFX artist in various video productions and was involved in global brands to small-scale music videos. He has 12 years of experience in the film industry and specializes in abstract expressions using computer graphics. He has also worked as a cinematographer and documentary director.

What opportunities do you see with MetaMask Snaps and the possibilities it unlocks for the Web3 space?

We believe that MetaMask Snaps will make complex Web3 technologies easier for both developers and users and will significantly help traditional Web applications integrate with Web3. We are as excited about creating MetaMask Snaps as we were when the first mobile app store came out. We encourage you to give it a try and realize your ideas!

Any advice you would like to share with developers keen to try MetaMask Snaps?

We recommend starting with the MetaMask Snaps template (https://github.com/MetaMask/template-snap-monorepo) and modifying it first.

Tip: You may be wondering how to get the injected ethereum object. The wallet object is equivalent to it.

Building with MetaMask Snaps

To get started with MetaMask Snaps:

  1. Checkout the developer docs
  2. Install MetaMask Flask
  3. Check out a MetaMask Snaps guide
  4. Stay connected with us on Twitter, GitHub discussions, and Discord

Keep an eye out for our team at the next hackathon in an area near you! Happy BUIDLing ⚒️

Disclaimer: MetaMask Snaps are generally developed by third parties other the ConsenSys Software. Use of third-party-developed MetaMask Snaps is done at your own discretion and risk and with agreement that you will solely be responsible for any loss or damage that results from such activities. Use of blockchain-related software carries risks, and you assume them in full when using MetaMask Snaps.

nodes.title: 10 Things You Can Do with MetaMask Portfolio
nodes.subtitle: Whether you’re an OG or newbie, the Fox is here to make you more powerful in web3. Here are 10 things you can do today in MetaMask Portfolio.

image.title: 10 Things You Can Do with MetaMask Portfolio

childMarkdownRemark.html:
The MetaMask wallet has been around almost as long as web3 itself. Launched in 2016, the Fox has come a long way since then, guided by a mission to connect as many people around the world to the decentralized internet as possible. And we know connecting is just the start - much more than that MetaMask enables you to buy, sell, swap, bridge, stake, and beyond, and it all starts in Portfolio.

MetaMask Portfolio is where you get a clear, comprehensive view of your accounts and wallets across all networks. It’s also where your web3 journey begins. Whether you’ve been using MetaMask for years or even minutes, here are ten things you can do in Portfolio right now:

Ten ways MetaMask Portfolio makes you powerful in web3


1. Manage your digital assets and track performance in the dashboard: Easily view and manage all your digital assets including Ethereum tokens (ERC-20) and non-fungible tokens (NFTs), all from a single, unified interface. Keep an eye on your portfolio's performance over time, with insights into asset distribution, historical transactions, and overall value trends. Remember you can view the balances of any public Ethereum address or ENS. You can also view which airdrops you’re eligible for by using the claim airdrop feature.

How to use the Dashboard on MetaMask Portfolio:




2. Do your taxes: Yes, that’s correct – you can do your crypto taxes directly from Portfolio. All you have to do is connect your wallet and you’ll receive 10% off your tax services with recommended providers like CoinTracker, CoinLedger, ZenLedger, Crypto Tax Calculator, and Koinly:


3. Connect to dapps and explore web3: Access and engage with all the dapps web3 has to offer directly through Portfolio: from decentralized finance (DeFi) platforms like Aave, Uniswap, and Renzo, gaming dapps such as HyperPlay to NFT marketplaces like OpenSea.

4. Swap tokens: Use the built-in swap feature to trade tokens directly within Portfolio, leveraging the best available rates across multiple decentralized exchanges (DEXs).



5. Connect to multiple networks: Beyond Ethereum, MetaMask supports various Ethereum Virtual Machine (EVM)-compatible networks, allowing users to switch between networks like Binance Smart Chain, Polygon, Linea, and more.

6. Buy and sell cryptocurrency: Buy cryptocurrencies directly within MetaMask Portfolio using traditional payment methods such as bank transfers or credit cards, and through integrations with third-party providers like Paypal and Revoult. And if you’re ready to sell, Portfolio has you covered, simply connect your wallet and select your method to cash out.




7. Integrate with your hardware wallet: Enhance your security by connecting MetaMask to hardware wallets like Ledger or Trezor from Portfolio, combining the convenience of MetaMask with the robust security of cold storage.

8. Customize privacy settings: Adjust your privacy settings to your preference, including setting up a custom RPC for specific networks, managing connected sites, and reviewing permissions. Learn more about how to configure your privacy settings here.

9. Participate in staking: Stake your crypto directly through MetaMask Portfolio, participating in the decision-making processes of various protocols and earning rewards. In Portfolio, there are three options for staking, Validator, Pooled, and Liquid. The below tutorials show you how easy it is to start staking based on your preference.




10. Bridge tokens: Bridging tokens on MetaMask refers to the process of transferring digital assets or tokens from one blockchain network to another using MetaMask as the interface for the transaction. Bridging tokens is a powerful feature in Portfolio that enhances the interoperability between different blockchain networks, enabling users to leverage the unique advantages of each network.


Coming soon in Portfolio


Transfer assets from centralized exchanges (CEXs) like Coinbase and Binance directly to your MetaMask wallet, or between different accounts within MetaMask itself, with enhanced security and ease. Stay tuned for this feature coming soon in Portfolio.

MetaMask Portfolio not only simplifies the management of digital assets but also opens up a world of possibilities for users to explore and engage with the decentralized ecosystem, all while maintaining a high level of security and user control. Get started today.

nodes.title: MetaMask UI Update: Signature Redesign
nodes.subtitle: MetaMask Extension's new UI update makes reviewing signature requests simpler and clearer.

childMarkdownRemark.html:
We’re excited to introduce our latest UI update for MetaMask Extension, aimed at improving the readability of signature requests.

For All Users: Whether you're new to MetaMask or a seasoned user, you'll notice a fresh, more visually pleasing look when receiving signature requests. This update makes it easier to understand and review the actions you're about to approve.

How It Works: Starting with v12.2 of the MetaMask Extension, you'll see the redesigned interface for Permit and Sign In With Ethereum signatures. Don't worry if you don't see changes right away—we're rolling this out gradually to ensure a smooth transition.

In the coming months, we'll be extending this new UI to more signatures, transactions, and our Mobile app. Stay tuned for these updates!

To keep up with the latest on this rollout and other updates, follow us on Twitter @MetaMaskSupport and keep an eye on our Support Channel.

Want to Learn More? Dive deeper into the world of MetaMask signatures by checking out our support article.

Embrace clarity and enjoy peace of mind. Happy signing!

nodes.title: MetaMask UX Update: Improved Token Insights
nodes.subtitle: The new update provides a comprehensive understanding of your crypto assets with 24-hour percentage changes and detailed financial data per ERC20 token.

childMarkdownRemark.html:
We are excited to introduce two important enhancements to our token management feature:

  1. 24-Hour percentage changes in token lists
  2. Detailed financial data in token details

Your token lists will now display 24-hour percentage changes, allowing you to quickly assess price trends directly in MetaMask. You can also access detailed financial data, including price charts and market cap information, when you click on your ERC20 tokens.

This is now available in MetaMask Extension and is coming soon to Mobile.

The 24-hour percentage change will be visible in the main asset list view, while detailed financial data can be found by clicking on the specific ERC20 tokens.

Whether you're a seasoned investor or new to crypto, having easy access to price trends and detailed financial information helps you manage your portfolio more effectively. You can learn more about it in our support article.

Stay tuned for further updates. Enjoy!
